articles.headline: Boeing Can’t Fly Its 737 Max, but It’s Ready to Sell Its Safety
articles.snippet: The company knows travelers are wary of its plane, so it has prepared presentations with strategies for airlines to help win back the public’s trust.
articles.abstract: The company knows travelers are wary of its plane, so it has prepared presentations with strategies for airlines to help win back the public’s trust.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Boeing’s 737 Max jet was grounded in March, after two crashes killed 346 people, a question has loomed for the company: Would passengers be too scared to fly on the plane once it returned to the air?

articles.headline: Italy Is in a Hazelnut Cream-Filled Civil War
articles.snippet: With Italians’ appetite for snack food growing, Barilla and Ferrero are in a pitched battle to make sure their cookies come out on top.
articles.abstract: With Italians’ appetite for snack food growing, Barilla and Ferrero are in a pitched battle to make sure their cookies come out on top.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILAN — As Marianna Farina and her husband did some Christmas shopping on a windy night in Milan, she noticed lots of people walking around with small brown packages of cookies.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Anna Momigliano

articles.headline: Saudi Arabia Wants Your Next Vacation
articles.snippet: The oil-rich kingdom is betting on tourism to broaden its economy, but will visitors come?
articles.abstract: The oil-rich kingdom is betting on tourism to broaden its economy, but will visitors come?
articles.lead_paragraph: AL-UYAYNAH, Saudi Arabia — In a makeshift camp under a starry sky, Ghazi Al-Anazi talked about his experience in the fledgling Saudi tourist business. A decade ago, barely in his 20s, he started taking British business associates of his brother to see the wind-carved hills of the Saudi desert.
